title: Riot's official response to the community after the sandbox backlash

embed.description: A Riot employee was interviewed about the Sandbox Mode stance and this is what he had to say! reddit thread -

replies.body:
Comon this is just offensive to Riot.

>While there are very real skills one can develop in a hyperbolic time chamber, we never want that to be an expectation added onto an already high barrier to entry

This is what I read in "Rito pls" and I think it is really good point and from this point I also dont want to have sandbox.
Though I believe that there could be some solution of restricted sandbox similar to the one in Heroes of the storm.

The problem with that is that the only alternative to sandbox mode is playing real games or customs. In real games there isn't much leeway to experiment. You can't test out builds because people might call you a troll and ruin your experience and you can't easily practice your combos. While this is somewhat more possible to do in customs, it's still a massive timesink. If you want to try out builds you're going to have to farm for at least 30+ minutes. If you want to swap to an entirely different build you're going to have to farm for probably another 15 or so minutes to make up the gold you lose by selling your items. This isn't even including the fact that if you want to swap to a different champion you're going to have to restart the entire thing again.

What about changing the in game times? What if you want to practice power spikes? At the moment, players have to restart every time they pass that power spike. And what if the champion only spikes really late into the game? Are you really going to waste 40 minutes just to practice that power spike for a couple of minutes?

Combos can't be easily practiced because of mana and cooldowns. Want to practice flashing over walls or using combos involving flash? Tough luck, you're going to have to wait five minutes. Want to practice a combo using your ult? Tough luck, you're going to have to wait anywhere from one to three minutes. Want to practice combos on a champion with high mana costs? Sorry, you're out of mana.

Despite what Riot may say, a sandbox mode would have no impact on a "high barrier to entry" nor would it become an expectation of all players. The only players who would be 'expected' to use sandbox mode are players who are just trying to practice and improve. Other players probably wouldn't touch it unless they wanted to try out something or were bored. If new players used sandbox mode, they would still fall under the former category of players trying to improve. They wouldn't have to play through hundreds of games with diamond smurfs just to improve. They could learn in one hour what might take a normal player ten to twenty. The barrier to entry would probably even shrink because sandbox mode would make it easier for new players to practice and learn the game.

Riot has no reason to refuse to make sandbox mode. The game instantly becomes much easier to learn for new players, thus bringing in a greater amount of new players and decreasing the amount of new players dropping out of the game. Pros gain an easy way to develop their skills and run drills which results in better play and more fierce competition. This naturally leads to more entertaining games and therefore more money for Riot.

Riot favors practice through play rather than through training. They state that they don't want to see players hopping into sandbox mode when they want to practice. They want players to play the game normally. This is the equivalent of the NBA not wanting to see teams doing practice sessions. Professional basketball players shouldn't have to practice to improve because they can just play the game normally.

Riot fears players will be 'obligated' to hit sandbox mode whenever they want to practice. This is some very ignorant thinking. No matter how much you practice something, you need to be able to do it in a realistic environment. If they can't do the same things to real players then the practice is meaningless. By playing real games players put what they've been practicing into action. Players can practice all they want in sandbox mode but that practice needs to be backed up by experience. A skill can be practiced in sandbox mode but it needs to be perfected against real players. Riot's fears are unwarranted.

STAFOO it's not that their fears are unwarranted. THey simply don't want to waste the effort and money on something that they aren't sure about as opposed to investing in something that they know will generate revenue. It's dumb using NBA as an example. First of all, that analogy doesn't work because media covers practice sessions and the like with journalists. They have every reason to refuse sandbox mode. I'm guessing you just don't understand how difficult all this stuff is and how much it costs. Who's going to fund it? You? Cough up the money and the department of devs who will do it, manage it, maintain it, and keep it going. All the while continuing to pay them. Sometimes I wonder how old you guys are. This is basic business 101. As much as they like us fans and want our advice, their priority is money. It's why they came together as a company. It's why they focus a lot on skins and revenue generating themes. You can romanticize the reasons however you want but at the end of the day, if there is no money there is no incentive to continue this game at all.

The best ways businesses make profit and get wealthier is by saving money instead of recklessly spending it, which is what sandbox mode supporters are essentially asking for. It's like bunch of little kids who want sugary sweets before dinner and crying harder and harder.

>First of all, that analogy doesn't work because media covers practice sessions and the like with journalists. 

No, it's the same situation. The players are being told they can't practice because playing should be the 'unequivocal best way for a player to improve.' The only real difference is that NBA players could just practice anyways because their practice doesn't require the NBA to set anything up for them. They can just shoot free throws at their house or a park. They could also run drills pretty easily. League players don't have this freedom. There is no easy way to set up methods of practice. If they don't give us a way to practice outside of playing, then we can't expect to improve as quickly because the system limits what we can do. Your comment about the media is irrelevant because it has nothing to do with what I'm talking about.

>I'm guessing you just don't understand how difficult all this stuff is and how much it costs. Who's going to fund it? You? Cough up the money and the department of devs who will do it, manage it, maintain it, and keep it going.

There are people doing it for free because Riot has refused to do anything. The way [this one](https://www.reddit.com/r/leagueoflegends/comments/3fy5ng/league_sandbox_intwars_update_easy_download/) is setup is that the player hosts the server for the sandbox and connects to their own server. The people who made it don't have to maintain anything except patches. It doesn't cost them any money to let people use it. Furthermore, Riot already has a sandbox-type of server at their headquarters. This is very obvious if you watch any of the champion spotlights.

>As much as they like us fans and want our advice, their priority is money. It's why they came together as a company. It's why they focus a lot on skins and revenue generating themes. You can romanticize the reasons however you want but at the end of the day, if there is no money there is no incentive to continue this game at all.

Did you miss the part where I talked about greater player retention and a better competitive scene? Both would directly contribute to Riot's income. 

More players = more money. 
Better competition = better entertainment = more money.

Smite has sandbox mode where you're the only person playing and you get to test your god's abilities and new builds against minions and bots with 100,000 starting gold

rito should be taking notes

But that's all you have. Gold and Exp gain. What smite has for league might be a lot better, but what people want is different. They want to say use flash, and have it available 5 seconds after wards, or things like that.

Which shouldn't be hard to implement at all or cost much especially if it's just limited to custom games. It would definitely increase the incentive for people to create custom games, so they may have to adjust more servers to that but that's only an assumption who would really know long term how much stress it would put on the servers. Minor increases in my opinion but with all the revenue generated I can't see it being a downfall at all. Especially since most people would be enticed  to experiment on league and take their ideas into games thus increasing their willingness to play / buy things.

Was it ignorant of us to ask for a training mode and replay system? Was that ignorant of us????

Not at all. What's ignorant are the babyrage posts, and the ever abundant "Rito please" mentality. People get the feeling that just because they get coerced into buying skins that riot owes them something. The sense of entitlement I read in the vast majority of the QQ posts is ridiculous. Because of all this Riot has a hard time distinguishing people who are whining from people with actual criticisms. When champs get reworked, the only people who are incredibly vocal are the people who are pissing and moaning about the changes, no matter how overwhelmingly positive they may be.

People just complain, in large volume, about anything and everything. They want it all their way, and they don't want to wait. If riot makes them wait for gameplay changes or functionality changes they get ridiculed. The balance team has to deal with trying to make champions fair, not just immediately, but for the foreseeable future so that there aren't a million nerfs or buffs coming out every patch. Champion update team has to deal with taking the champions we know and love and make them better without spawning a massive angry mob outside of Riot headquarters. So many people bitched about Sion. Some actually complained about Ashe's lack of free crit and loss of gold revenue. Don't get me started on the polarization of the community on the GP changes. Fiora is just the current subject of controversy. 

This is what makes it hard for riot to listen. This is what makes balancing such a challenge. "Don't nerf my freelo plz" or "New Fiora sucks" aren't constructive comments or suggestions, and they flood the boards, and the youtube comments, and the reddit posts. Riot isn't perfect, the people who balance the game aren't perfect, the people who create new content aren't perfect. Yet, we the people, who are both toxic and non-toxic, who feed, carry, and flame and encourage, are all so different in what we want for ourselves in the game that we forget that nothing is perfect. Riot as a company has its own intentions for the direction of League of Legends, and when that doesn't match up with the greater desires of the playerbase the entitled and spoiled brats in the community start to show, and they overwhelm the people that want to have positive and meaningful conversation. Their views are absolute, they are jus there to complain without opening up to an alternate perspective.

It isn't ignorant to ask for certain things from the company. What's ignorant is to demand these things and accuse the company of not caring about its playerbase after they have explained their rationale and priorities. At that point, you aren't voicing your opinion. You're just being childish. At the end of the day Riot has all the say when it comes to these things, but that doesn't keep them from communicating with the community about their ideas. And no, it doesn't always work out for the best but that's what riot tries to learn from. They still have a long way to go though

As the patrons of League of Legends, Riot takes into account a lot of our feedback in order to make the game more enjoyable, and they are relatively transparent when it comes to process and intentions, but the players don't always know best, in fact, the players are the most biased party, each one with their own individual agenda which is why everyone isn't going to be happy, and sometimes even the majority isn't happy and that's ok, because half of the time the majority gets the fuck over it. Plenty of people even asked for the jungle to stay the same as it was in S4. Riot tweaked the game enough for people to survive in the new jungle but that was pretty much it. Yet look at the meta now. Almost anything works if you can play it well. 
 
Like kids not wanting to eat their veggies, sometimes you don't know what's good for you. Nothing wrong with having an opinion, because it's just that, an opinion. I definitely think that if enough people make a constructive argument that Riot may listen and decide to implement sand box mode after all.  Playing a game of league should be the best way of bettering yourself as a whole. There's no other place to really have the best learning experience in lane or team comp. However certain skills and end game scenarios do not come up often enough in a way that enables learning those skills. It hinders players in a way that could annoy them to no end because they will repeatedly fail flash at 3 different points on the map and can't seem to get them down.  Spread out over 30 games that on average last about 40 minutes they might need to flash at those points 30 times so once per game at those locations. If they're being chased and are low on health that can cost them a kill, an entire team fight if they were flashing over to start engaging, and in some cases the entire game if it was a crucial fight. 

Is it really the best way to learn when you can be so discouraged and upset with yourself for failing to flash at the same points but yet not sure the best timing to flash over those locations? No it'd be easier to learn by the visual cues by actually doing it a few time. Which could be one 20 minute session saving maybe 3 or 5 40 minute games that would end in a loss out of those 30. 


Also to be fair the numbers I'm using are pure speculation and are not indicative of actual results. I just think sand box mode is practical and can help with practice.....honestly I see a lot of people do bots for the same thing and often can't even practice what they were really wanting to because of other players or how long the game lasts. So yeah, I hope riot reconsiders.
